Yesterday a series of balloons popped up on the Arts Quad for the second year in a row. At the base of each balloon was a handwritten note of encouragement from one Cornellian to another. Lifted Cornell hopes to grow into a campus organization soon, stay tuned!

Taking advantage of the relative quiet of Duffield Hall's atrium during this Tuesday afternoon during spring break, mechanical engineering doctoral students Matthew Sheen, left, and Matthew Kelly, right, take Cornell's Ranger robot for walking laps of the atrium to log data and test various controllers.
Ranger, a four-legged bipedal robot, has previously set distance-walking and single-battery-charge robotic walking records; Kelly says they are now working using machine learning for Ranger so that it can optimize its controllers and improve its walking efficiency, even on slightly uneven floors.

Rich Medina ’92 speaks about the trajectory, aesthetics and culture of hip-hop Tuesday in the Cornell’s Adult University course Hip Hop: Its History, Music and Culture.
Students from Cornell's Telluride House joined the CAU participants for the morning session.
Medina, a DJ and advisory board member for the Cornell Hip Hop Collection, is being assisted by Ben Ortiz and Katherine Reagan, curators of the collection in the library’s Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections.
The weeklong course includes lectures and discussions that delve into sound recordings, images and videos, as well as guest appearances by local artists as participants explore hip-hop’s core artistic elements of DJing, rapping, breakdancing and graffiti.
@cornellhiphopcollection @cornell_library @cornellcau

With the goal of sustaining healthier oceans, C. Drew Harvell, professor of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, has led a coalition of more than 40 scientists to understand, document & provide solutions for marine life. Harvell’s team recently explored the vital role seagrass meadows has on the health of surrounding ecosystems. Their research found that sea grass meadows, in addition to sheltering species, also fight diseases that potentially threaten marine life. Harvell reflects, “Our research is always in an environmental context, because we’re studying the way ocean change drives ecologically important things.”

"Herakles in Ithaka I" reflects a streak of sun following a humid, mid-afternoon rain shower. Crafted out of welded steel parts from automobile bumpers, the sculpture was designed by Jason Seley '40, an art professor from 1968 to 1973. After his time spent in the classroom, Seley went on to become dean of the college in 1980, creating Herakles the following year.

The group rides 15-30 miles a day during this week’s daily biking trips. "This has been an incredible week with the biking – catching up with my undergraduate roommate from years ago, and meeting many new people, but also seeing sights throughout Cornell and Ithaca, that are stunning, that I’ve never seen before,” says Julie Crotty ’86, J.D./MBA ’96. @cornellcau @cornelloutdoors @cornellalumni

Cornell Campus: Fuertes Observatory is located on a hill on the North Campus of Cornell University, near Helen Newman.
Fuertes is no longer used for professional research. Instead, a few introductory astronomy classes hold lab sessions there. There are also public viewing nights on clear Fridays, from 9pm to midnight. Call 255 3557 to find out if Fuertes is currently open. Public viewing nights are run by the Cornell Astronomical Society.

Members of CUMEME, the Cornell University Middle Eastern Music Ensemble, perform Sunday afternoon in downtown Ithaca as part of Ithaca’s 10th Annual Porchfest.
Porchfest is an annual music festival "celebrating the vital creative community of downtown Ithaca, New York.” It has grown from 20 performers the first year to 180 in 2015. Following Ithaca’s lead, there are now at least 55 other Porchfests around the U.S. and Canada. Ithaca’s Porchfest is sponsored by longtime partner Ithaca Neighborhood Housing Services (INHS).
CUMEME is a Cornell student organization that performs traditional Arabic, Persian, Turkish, Greek and other music from the Middle East. Other Cornell groups participating in Porchfest included the Cornell Ukulele Club and the Cornell Gamlean Ensemble.

The Klarman Hall time capsule is now sealed and buried, awaiting its discovery by future Cornell students during Cornell’s bicentennial year in 2065. Sheldon Borden, left, and Ray Wilson, carpenters with Local 277, completed the project July 19.
The time capsule was created to celebrate the university’s new humanities building and includes items that tell the tale of life as we know it in 2016 selected by a faculty committee and designed by a group of students with contributions from faculty members, students and alumni. Photo: Patrick Shanahan. @cornellcas

Participants in the Cornell's Adult University course Hip Hop: Its History, Music and Culture observe a cypher (breakdancing/b-boy exhibition, demonstration) by three Cornell graduate students Wednesday morning in Kroch Library. Pictured at center is Andrew Klapproth ’18 (he is president of Absolute Zero, Cornell’s breakdancing crew).
The class is being taught by Rich Medina ’92, a DJ and advisory board member for the Cornell Hip Hop Collection, with assistance by Ben Ortiz and Katherine Reagan, curators of the collection in Cornell University Library's Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections.
The weeklong course includes lectures and discussions that delve into sound recordings, images and videos, as well as guest appearances by local artists as participants explore hip-hop’s core artistic elements of DJing, rapping, breakdancing and graffiti.
‪@cornellhiphopcollection @cornell_library @cornellcau @ortizben @reagankat

One of the Veterans Day events held today at Cornell is the Moving Flag Tribute, in which the Veterans Colleague Network Group and the Cornell Reserve Officers in Training Corps invited members of the university community to accompany them as they move flags across campus continuously from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., honoring all veterans as well as active duty and reserve servicemen and women.
Cornell also is participating in the national “Greenlight a Vet” campaign; the Adopt a Soldier Program; hosting the photographic collection of Glenn Hoover ’68, a Vietnam veteran; and has launched a new university veterans’ website, military.cornell.edu.

Uris Library’s 125th birthday was celebrated Thursday afternoon with festivities, pumpkin cake, decorations and giveaways.
Pumpkin cake (and decorations) were chosen in honor of the pumpkin which mysteriously appeared on top of McGraw Tower in October 1997.
Uris Library, the university’s oldest, opened in 1891 as Cornell’s first library building, designed by architect William Henry Miller, who had studied at Cornell. It contains the A.D. White Library, a library within a library, designed by the university’s first president, Andrew Dickson White. @rarecornell @cornell_library

Students in the landscape architecture and horticulture course "Creating the Urban Eden" plant ground cover plants, including new varieties of cultivars, outside Teagle Hall across from Barton Hall Thursday afternoon.
The two-semester course, which is co-taught by Peter Trowbridge (landscape architecture chair) and Nina Bassuk (professor of horticulture), attracts mostly landscape architecture students; they design gardens, new landscaping and legacy plantings for several spots around campus in the fall and then install their designed creations in the spring — what Trowbridge calls an ideal example of theory to practice.

The Cornell International Fair is being held today (11:30 a.m. to 2 p.m.) on the Uris Hall first floor terrace, and showcases the many options for students to internationalize their Cornell experience.
Undergraduate and graduate students explored international and global study on campus and abroad and, by talking with faculty and staff, found out more about study abroad, exchanges, language study, international majors and minors, fellowships, internships, courses with international travel components and service learning.
The fair was jointly organized by the Mario Einaudi Center for International Studies at Cornell University, Cornell Abroad: Office of International Education and the Language Resource Center.

Hudson Valley, New York-based artist Nestor Madalengoitia applauds Friday afternoon immediately after unveiling “Ezra Cornell,” a mural celebrating the history and future of Tompkins County Public Library. @nestorartstudio
The mural, installed on the exterior wall of the Tompkins County Public Library along Cayuga Street in downtown Ithaca, honors Ezra Cornell's founding of what was originally the Cornell Free Library in 1864 -- one year before the founding of Cornell University.

Next month will mark the 150th anniversary of the completion of the library, which originally was located at Tioga and Seneca streets in downtown Ithaca. The mural, depicting Ezra Cornell’s face and concentric circular script, includes a quote by Francis Miles Finch, an Ithaca native and Yale-educated lawyer, who assisted Ezra Cornell in drawing up the charter for a library association:
“It belongs to all. Let that be remembered. Not to a chosen few to monopolize its benefits, not to a narrow circle to frown on all the rest, but to all, to every one as equal with every other.” Madalengoitia’s mural is one of three public art murals funded in part or in full by the Community Arts Partnership of Tompkins County’s public art grant. @tcplny

Members of the Cornell Gamlean Ensemble perform Sunday afternoon in downtown Ithaca as part of Ithaca’s 10th Annual Porchfest.
Porchfest is an annual music festival "celebrating the vital creative community of downtown Ithaca, New York” and has grown from 20 performers the first year to 180 in 2015.
Following Ithaca’s lead, there are now at least 55 other Porchfests around the U.S. and Canada.
The Cornell Gamelan Ensemble plays various styles of gamelan — the term for ensembles of bronze gongs and metallophones, with assorted other instruments — but focuses primarily on that from Central Java. It consists of Cornell students and faculty, as well as members from the Ithaca community and beyond.
Other Cornell groups participating in Porchfest included the Cornell Ukulele Club and the Cornell University Middle Eastern Music Ensemble.

Twenty-five years ago, on February 6, 1992, the Big Red Barn opened its doors as the Graduate and Professional Student Center (GPSC), providing a gathering place for students to eat, relax and socialize. Since its founding, the Big Red Barn has grown to host 300 events a year and continues to foster a community for graduate students. Kris Corda, director of the center, reflects on its impact, “Through the years, I have received so many notes that the Barn was a place students cherished, a place where they met some of their very best friends.”

Members of the Crazeology dance troupe and The Original Cornell Syncopators, a new student music group, perform at Barnes Hall Sunday evening in a concert held to mark and honor the 100th anniversary of the Feb. 26, 1917 recording session that produced what would become the first jazz record, “Livery Stable Blues.” The concert, presented by the Department of Music with guests Crazeology, Paul Merrill and Troy Anderson, recreated the recording session by The Original Dixieland Jass Band and also included a period-piece live music-and-dance performance “A Night at Reisenweber’s,” set at New York’s famed Reisenweber’s Café.
The project is the brainchild of cornet player Colin Hancock ’19. Other members include Hannah Krall, clarinet; Rishi Verma, trombone; Amit Mizrahi, piano; Noah Li, drums; and coach and Ithaca jazz veteran Joe Salzano.

In honor of Veterans Day, McGraw Tower was lit in green very early this morning and will be again late this afternoon to honor veterans as part of the national “Greenlight a Vet” campaign.
“‘Greenlight A Vet’ aims to build a bridge for veterans and civilians to connect and start a conversation,” says David Outlaw ’17, president of the Cornell Undergraduate Veterans Association. “Cornell will light McGraw Tower green, so even if we can’t always see our veterans, they can always see our support.” This special lighting in honor of veterans will become an annual event.

Corey Ryan Earle '07 gives "The First American University: A Talk on the History of Cornell" presentation Thursday in Call Auditorium in Kennedy Hall. The historic tour through university history and lore was sponsored by the Cornell Senior Class Campaign 2017, partnered with the 2017 Class Council.
The historic photo on the screen shows the Beebe Lake toboggan slide, which operated from 1902-49. The large wooden slide (replaced by steel in 1912) sent Cornellians hurtling down the south shore of Beebe Lake onto the ice at high speeds. The slide was eventually dismantled, in part because of safety concerns.

A moment in the lab with NYC agriculture expert Philson Warner: Founder of hydroponics and aquaculture laboratories at a Manhattan high school, Warner grows students into young scientists with his experiential and inquiry-based curriculum. Warner reflects, “Our greenhouse — with its mutually sustainable hydroponic and aquaculture systems — is used for teaching, food production and as a science hub for the New York City area. Using minimal energy, it may even contribute to the city's power grid.”

Nineteenth century artwork featured at the @hfjmuseum. The exhibition's "salon-style hang" originated in Paris, where paintings were hung from floor to ceiling in order to maximize space. This particular style eventually aided in how American art was displayed in public museums.

Happy Monday! Classic winter morning walk up the Slope to campus for classes.

During a Q&A session at Bailey Hall, President Martha Pollack reflected on her academic background, shared her experience in Ithaca so far, and outlined a vision for Cornell’s future. Pollack discussed her four pillars that she intends to focus on: academics, engagement in education innovation, free speech and building our community. Pictured: President Pollack, VP of University Relations Joel Malina and Trustee Liz Everett Krisberg ’97 applaud after singing the alma mater with a packed Reunion crowd. Before she took the stage, Pollack also chatted with 9th president Frank H.T. Rhodes.

Take a study break and explore “Wake the Form,” a unique set of books at the Carl A. Kroch Library’s Hirshland Gallery. The exhibit showcases fine printing, artists’ books, and other rare editions collected through the years. 📖📚 ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀

Launched 40 years ago, @NASA’s Voyager spacecraft carries a unique "time capsule" in the form of a Golden Record curated by Cornell professor Carl Sagan. One of only a handful of covers that remain on Earth is currently on public display for the first time at @Cornell_Library. ⠀

Happy 90th birthday, President Emeritus Frank H.T. Rhodes! Here he is serenaded by family members, friends and colleagues during a symposium in his honor today in Statler Auditorium.
The former president is a geologist and Darwin scholar who led Cornell from 1977-95. Today’s symposium celebrated the intellectual cornerstones of his academic career (which continues today; his new book, “Origins: The Search for Our Prehistoric Past,” was published just last month).
